answer_html: There are \(126\) ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
answer_latex: There are $126$ ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
hints_html: In contrast to part (a), the order in which one chooses his courses does not matter. So this is just a combinations question.
hints_latex:
In contrast to
{part
(a)}, the order in which one chooses his courses does not matter. So
this is just a combinations question.
hints_raw: In contrast to [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_Section_001_10_(a)|part (a)]], the order in which one chooses his courses does not matter. So this is just a combinations question.
question: Section 001 10 (b)
sols_html:
When selecting courses, the order does not matter. So I am really interested in a combination here. I have want to select \(5\) of the \(9\) available courses, so I am looking at \(\binom{9}{5}\).

\[\begin{aligned} \binom{9}{5} &= \frac{9!}{5! (9-5)!}\\ &= \frac{9!}{5!}\cdot \frac{1}{4!}\\ &= \frac{9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot 6}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1}\\ &= 9\cdot2\cdot7 \\ &=126\end{aligned}\]

There are \(126\) ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
sols_latex:
When selecting courses, the order does not matter. So I am really
interested in a combination here. I have want to select $5$ of the $9$
available courses, so I am looking at $\binom{9}{5}$.

\begin{align*}
\binom{9}{5} &= \frac{9!}{5! (9-5)!}\\
&= \frac{9!}{5!}\cdot \frac{1}{4!}\\
&= \frac{9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot 6}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1}\\
&= 9\cdot2\cdot7 \\
&=126
\end{align*}

There are $126$ ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
sols_raw:
When selecting courses, the order does not matter. So I am really interested in a combination here. I have want to select <math>5</math> of the <math>9</math> available courses, so I am looking at <math>\binom{9}{5}</math>.

<math>\begin{align}
\binom{9}{5} &= \frac{9!}{5! (9-5)!}\\
&= \frac{9!}{5!}\cdot \frac{1}{4!}\\
&= \frac{9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot 6}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1}\\
&= 9\cdot2\cdot7 \\
&=126
\end{align}</math>

There are <math>126</math> ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
statement_html:
There are \(9\) courses I want to take next term. All \(9\) courses are offered during the same \(5\) time slots. How many ways do I have to fill those \(5\) time slots?

For this question, a numerical answer is required as a final answer.
statement_latex:
There are $9$ courses I want to take next term. All $9$ courses are
offered during the same $5$ time slots. How many ways do I have to fill
those $5$ time slots?

\emph{For this question, a numerical answer is required as a final
answer.}
statement_raw:
There are <math>9</math> courses I want to take next term. All <math>9</math> courses are offered during the same <math>5</math> time slots. How many ways do I have to fill those <math>5</math> time slots?

''For this question, a numerical answer is required as a final answer.''
